about.content: I am an aspiring software engineer studying Computer Science at Dartmouth. I began my coding career at Los Gatos High School, and since then have taken courses in Software Design and Implementation, Algorithms, Applied Cryptography, Full-Stack Web Development, Machine Learning and Statistical Analysis, among other areas.

At Dartmouth I have experience working as a teacher’s assistant and as a developer for HackDartmouth, the club which organizes the annual Dartmouth hackathon. I also had some amazing internships at Minerva Networks, Grove Collaborative, and NVIDIA.

Through my academics and professional experience, I’ve learned Java, Python, C, PHP, and Javascript. I’m familiar with frameworks such as React, React-Native, Node, and Flask. I’ve also used tools such as Airflow, Selenium, MongoDB, Docker and Heroku for deployment, and Git for version control.
Aside from CS, I spend most of my time playing ultimate frisbee with Dartmouth’s PainTrain and organizing Dartmouth’s annual hackathon with HackDartmouth.

experience.content: I currently work as a software engineer for the platform team.
experience.title: Grove Collaborative

experience.content: At NVIDIA, I joined the software security tools team. I created a web service which synthesized data from multiple sources into a bulletin documenting security vulnerabilities. I utilized Angular, Flask, SQLAlchemy, and Pandas to manipulate and display the data.
experience.title: NVIDIA

experience.content: I built API endpoints with Django's REST framework to automate a labor-intensive cancellation process, and I helped the customer support team by developing Zendesk filtering scripts.
experience.title: Grove Collaborative

experience.content: I worked as a Teacher's Assistant for CS50 - Software Design and Implementation. I orchestrated weekly recitation sessions, supervised a final project team, and graded all labs.
experience.title: Teacher's Assistant

experience.content: I designed and developed a quality assurance tool to verify the synchronization between a 3rd party encryption server and a company server. The tool used HTML and JavaScript for the user interface, while PHP handled the server queries.
experience.title: Minerva Networks

experience.content: I worked as a QA software engineer where I devised automated soak test scripts which simulated user input. I self-taught myself the PERL programming language and reported bugs I found in Jira.
experience.title: Minerva Networks

experience.content: I wrote automated test scripts in Java using Selenium and StormTest. The scripts tested CSS styles or took a snapshot and compared it to an expected image.
experience.title: Minerva Networks

portfolio.content: For the final project in my databases class, we built Chef's Kiss, a place to share and find recipes. It comes fully equipped with account authentication, search, favorites, and a small database of recipes. It's deployed on Heroku using a React frontend and an Express/MySQL backend. Check out the code here!

For my culminating experience at Dartmouth, we built a phone app for managing foodstuffs. The app has three components, a React Native frontend, an Express and MongoDB backend, and a flask microservice for managing voice. Check it out here!

For the final project in web development, we created Quiplash without a paywall by utilizing websockets to keep open connections throughout the game. Check out the game, as well as the frontend and the backend code.
I developed this website with React to show off my portfolio and practice my web development skills. All the styling was done with pure css. Curious about the code?
As a developer and director of HackDartmouth, I managed 5 teams of roughly 14 people to organize Dartmouth's annual hackathon. I also coordinated the creation of the new HackDartmouth site.

**Tiny-Search Engine:** A simple search engine that takes in a search query from the user, crawls the web, indexes the pages found, and outputs a ranked list of search results. Click here to view the code on Github.
As part of my computational linguistics class, we hypothesized that word2vec could be used to easily test biases between news sources. Check out our findings!
We built an audio visualizer with a Digilent FPGA, a mic, a VGA monitor, and VHDL. Check out the ![demonstration](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gN6DgaZrZ-A&feature=youtu.be) or the project writeup.
